dialogs.original: Can no man tell me of my unthrifty son?    'Tis full three months since I did see him last;    If any plague hang over us, 'tis he.    I would to God, my lords, he might be found:    Inquire at London, 'mongst the taverns there,    For there, they say, he daily doth frequent,    With unrestrained loose companions,    Even such, they say, as stand in narrow lanes,    And beat our watch, and rob our passengers;    Which he, young wanton and effeminate boy,    Takes on the point of honour to support    So dissolute a crew.
dialogs.translated: Cant anyone tell me where my wasteful son has gone? I havent seen him for three months; if we have a plague, its him. I wish we could find himask around at London, among the taverns, for they say he spends his time there with the sort of companions who rob people in the streets, while he, young, stupid, and effeminate boy, spends my money supporting that crew.

dialogs.original: My lord, some two days since I saw the prince,And told him of those triumphs held at Oxford.
dialogs.translated: My lord, I saw the prince about two days ago, and told him about the tournament happening at Oxford.

dialogs.original: And what said the gallant?
dialogs.translated: And what did the young man say?

dialogs.original: His answer was, he would unto the stews,    And from the common'st creature pluck a glove,    And wear it as a favour;   and with that    He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.
dialogs.translated: He said he would go to the slums and take a glove from a beggar, and wear it as a favor, and with that would defeat the champion in a joust.

dialogs.original: As dissolute as desperate;   yet through both    I see some sparks of better hope, which elder years    May happily bring forth. But who comes here?
dialogs.translated: Foolish and out-of-control; yet even so, I see some sparks of something better which might come out when hes older. But whos here now?

dialogs.original: Where is the king?
dialogs.translated: Where is the king?

dialogs.original: What means our cousin, that he stares and looksSo wildly?
dialogs.translated: What's wrong with youwhy do you look so wild?

dialogs.original: God save your grace! I do beseech your majesty,To have some conference with your grace alone.
dialogs.translated: God save your grace! I beg you to give me some time to talk to you alone.

dialogs.original: Withdraw yourselves, and leave us here alone.
dialogs.translated: Leave us alone.

dialogs.original: What is the matter with our cousin now?
dialogs.translated: What is the matter with our cousin now?

dialogs.original: For ever may my knees grow to the earth,My tongue cleave to my roof within my mouthUnless a pardon ere I rise or speak.
dialogs.translated: [Kneels]May my knees grow into the earth and my tongue stick to roof of my mouth, unless you pardon me before I stand up or speak.

dialogs.original: Intended or committed was this fault?    If on the first, how heinous e'er it be,    To win thy after-love I pardon thee.
dialogs.translated: Did you intend to do something wrong, or did you already do it? If its the first, no matter how bad it is, Ill forgive you to make you love me from now on.

dialogs.original: Then give me leave that I may turn the key,That no man enter till my tale be done.
dialogs.translated: Then let me lock the door, so that no one can come in until I've explained myself.

dialogs.original: Have thy desire.
dialogs.translated: As you wish.

dialogs.original: [Within]  My liege, beware; look to thyself;Thou hast a traitor in thy presence there.
dialogs.translated: (From outside the door) My liege, beware; protect yourself; you have a traitor in there with you.

dialogs.original: Villain, I'll make thee safe.
dialogs.translated: Villain, I know how to protect myself.

dialogs.original: Stay thy revengeful hand; thou hast no cause to fear.
dialogs.translated: Wait, don't draw your sword; you have no reason to be afraid.

dialogs.original: [Within]   Open the door, secure, foolhardy king:    Shall I for love speak treason to thy face?    Open the door, or I will break it open.
dialogs.translated: [Outside] Open this locked door, foolish king: will you make me speak in this treasonous way to you when I'm trying to protect you? Open the door, or I will break it open.

dialogs.original: What is the matter, uncle?   speak;    Recover breath; tell us how near is danger,    That we may arm us to encounter it.
dialogs.translated: Whats the matter, uncle? Speak [wheezes]; recover breath. Tell us how close we are to danger, so that we can protect ourselves.

dialogs.original: Peruse this writing here, and thou shalt knowThe treason that my haste forbids me show.
dialogs.translated: [Shows the letter]Read this, and youll know about the treason that Im too out of breath to explain.

dialogs.original: Remember, as thou read'st, thy promise pass'd:    I do repent me;   read not my name there    My heart is not confederate with my hand.
dialogs.translated: Remember, as you read, what you promised me! Im sorry for what I did; dont see my name signed there, since my hand didnt follow my heart.

dialogs.original: It was, villain, ere thy hand did set it down.    I tore it from the traitor's bosom, king;    Fear, and not love, begets his penitence:    Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove    A serpent that will sting thee to the heart.
dialogs.translated: Your heart was with them even before you signed this. I took it from the traitor, king; fear, and not love, motivates his confession now. Dont forgive him, lest you regret your pity later when he stabs you in the back.

dialogs.original: O heinous, strong and bold conspiracy   !    O loyal father of a treacherous son!    Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain,    From when this stream through muddy passages    Hath held his current and defiled himself!    Thy overflow of good converts to bad,    And thy abundant goodness shall excuse    This deadly blot in thy digressing son.
dialogs.translated: Oh, horrible plot! Oh, loyal father of a treacherous soon! Youre a clear fountain and hes the stream that muddies your water. But your overflow of goodness will redeem your son, even though hes committed a crime punishable by death.

dialogs.original: So shall my virtue be his vice's bawd;    And he shall spend mine honour with his shame,    As thriftless sons their scraping fathers' gold.    Mine honour lives when his dishonour dies,    Or my shamed life in his dishonour lies:    Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath,    The traitor lives, the true man's put to death.
dialogs.translated: My virtue will pay for his vice, then, so that he can spend my honor with his shame, like a spendthrift son who steals his fathers money. You dishonour me by letting him live: the traitor survives, the true man dies.

dialogs.original: [Within]  What ho, my liege! for God's sake,let me in.
dialogs.translated: [Outside]Are you there, my liege? For Gods sake, let me in.

dialogs.original: What shrill-voiced suppliant makes this eager cry?
dialogs.translated: What shrill-voiced petitioner is shouting at us?

dialogs.original: A woman, and thy aunt, great king; 'tis I.Speak with me, pity me, open the door.A beggar begs that never begg'd before.
dialogs.translated: A woman, and your aunt, great king: it's me. Speak with me, take pity on me, open the door. I'm a beggar that's never begged before.

dialogs.original: Our scene is alter'd from a serious thing,And now changed to 'The Beggar and the King.'My dangerous cousin, let your mother in:I know she is come to pray for your foul sin.
dialogs.translated: This scene now looks less like a serious thing, and more like "The Beggar and the King." My dangerous cousin, let your mother in: I know she's come to pray that I forgive you for your crime.

dialogs.original: If thou do pardon, whosoever pray,    More sins for this forgiveness prosper may.    This fester'd joint cut off, the rest rest sound;    This let alone will all the rest confound.
dialogs.translated: If you forgive him, whoever prays against it, bad things will come of it. If you cut off this diseased limb, the rest of the body will live; but if you leave it, it will poison you.

dialogs.original: O king, believe not this hard-hearted man!Love loving not itself none other can.
dialogs.translated: Oh king, don't believe this hard-hearted man! He doesn't know how to love his own, so how can he love you?

dialogs.original: Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here?Shall thy old dugs once more a traitor rear?
dialogs.translated: You crazy woman, what are you doing here? Shall your old breasts wean another traitor?

dialogs.original: Sweet York, be patient. Hear me, gentle liege.
dialogs.translated: Sweet York, shut up. Listen to me, gentle liege.

dialogs.original: Rise up, good aunt.
dialogs.translated: Get up, good aunt.

dialogs.original: Not yet, I thee beseech:    For ever will I walk upon my knees,    And never see day that the happy sees,    Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy,    By pardoning Rutland, my transgressing boy.
dialogs.translated: Not yet, I beseech you: I'll stay on my knees forever and never have a happy day in my life, until you give me joy again by pardoning Rutland, my son, who has offended you.

dialogs.original: Unto my mother's prayers I bend my knee.
dialogs.translated: [Kneeling]  I kneel to add my pleas to my mother's.

dialogs.original: Against them both my true joints bended be.Ill mayst thou thrive, if thou grant any grace!
dialogs.translated: [Kneels] I kneel against them with my loyal joints! It won't go well for you, if you grant any forgiveness!

dialogs.original: Pleads he in earnest? look upon his face;    His eyes do drop no tears, his prayers are in jest;    His words come from his mouth, ours from our breast:    He prays but faintly and would be denied;    We pray with heart and soul and all beside:    His weary joints would gladly rise, I know;    Our knees shall kneel till to the ground they grow:    His prayers are full of false hypocrisy;    Ours of true zeal and deep integrity.    Our prayers do out-pray his; then let them have    That mercy which true prayer ought to have.
dialogs.translated: Do you think he really means it? Look at his face; he's not crying, his prayers are false; his words come from his mouth, but ours from our hearts. He begs weakly and would rather that you not grant his request; we pray with heart and soul and everything else. His tired joints would rather rise, I know; our knees will kneel to the ground until they take root there. His prayers are full of false hypocrisy; ours are full of true emotion and deep honesty. Our prayers out-pray hisso let us have the mercy which true prayer should receive.

dialogs.original: Good aunt, stand up.
dialogs.translated: Good aunt, stand up.

dialogs.original: Nay, do not say, 'stand up;'    Say, 'pardon' first, and afterwards 'stand up.'    And if I were thy nurse, thy tongue to teach,    'Pardon' should be the first word of thy speech.    I never long'd to hear a word till now;    Say 'pardon,' king; let pity teach thee how:    The word is short, but not so short as sweet;    No word like 'pardon' for kings' mouths so meet.
dialogs.translated: No, don't say "stand up"; say "pardon" first, and "stand up" afterwards. If I were your nurse teaching you your first words, "pardon" would be the first word you knew. I never wanted to hear any word so much; say "pardon," king, and let pity teach you how: the word is short, but short is sweet, and no word is better to hear from a king.

dialogs.original: Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'
dialogs.translated: [Sarcastically] Speak it in French, king; say, 'pardonne moi.'

dialogs.original: Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy?    Ah, my sour husband, my hard-hearted lord,    That set'st the word itself against the word!    Speak 'pardon' as 'tis current in our land;    The chopping French we do not understand.    Thine eye begins to speak; set thy tongue there;    Or in thy piteous heart plant thou thine ear;    That hearing how our plaints and prayers do pierce,    Pity may move thee 'pardon' to rehearse.
dialogs.translated: Are you trying to ruin this? Oh, my bitter husband, my hard-hearted lord, to set our words against yours! [To Bolingbroke] Say "pardon" as we do it in our country; we don't understand French. Your eye begins to say it; may your tongue say it too; or put your heart in your ear, so that, hearing our prayers, it might take pity on us and command your mouth to say the words.

dialogs.original: Good aunt, stand up.
dialogs.translated: Good aunt, stand up.

dialogs.original: I do not sue to stand;Pardon is all the suit I have in hand.
dialogs.translated: I don't beg to stand; I only ask for pardon.

dialogs.original: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.
dialogs.translated: I pardon him, as God shall pardon me.

dialogs.original: O happy vantage of a kneeling knee!    Yet am I sick for fear: speak it again;    Twice saying 'pardon' doth not pardon twain,    But makes one pardon strong.
dialogs.translated: Oh, happy outcome from my kneeling! But I am still afraid; say it again. Two pardons is better than one.

dialogs.original: With all my heartI pardon him.
dialogs.translated: With all my heart I pardon him.

dialogs.original: A god on earth thou art.
dialogs.translated: You're a god on earth.

dialogs.original: But for our trusty brother-in-law and the abbot,    With all the rest of that consorted crew,    Destruction straight shall dog them at the heels.    Good uncle, help to order several powers    To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are:    They shall not live within this world, I swear,    But I will have them, if I once know where.    Uncle, farewell: and, cousin too, adieu:    Your mother well hath pray'd, and prove you true.
dialogs.translated: But as for our trusty brother-in-law and the abbot, they'll be destroyed with the rest of the plotters. Good uncle, help us send an army to Oxford, or wherever the traitors are: they won't live much longer if I can help it, once we find them. Uncle, goodbye, and cousin too; your mother has begged well for you, so be loyal going forward.

dialogs.original: Come, my old son: I pray God make thee new.
dialogs.translated: Come on, my old son; I hope God makes you new.
